pullrequest.title: Allow `gz log` to output to a file

content.raw:
Thanks. It doesn't segfault anymore, but it still doesn't start recording.

If I do this:

`$ gz log -d 1`

It records to a timestamped directory in `~/.gazebo/log/`

I expected to choose an output file like this:

`$ gz log -d 1 -o ~/testlog2.log`

But it doesn't record anything and gives me this error:

`No source log file specified. Use the -f command line argument.`
content.html:
Thanks. It doesn't segfault anymore, but it still doesn't start recording.

If I do this:

$ gz log -d 1

It records to a timestamped directory in ~/.gazebo/log/

I expected to choose an output file like this:

$ gz log -d 1 -o ~/testlog2.log

But it doesn't record anything and gives me this error:

No source log file specified. Use the -f command line argument.

pull_request.title: Allow `gz log` to output to a file

pullrequest.title: Allow `gz log` to output to a file

content.raw:
If you have gazebo installed in the system, this gz command probably will use it instead of the compiled one.

I've [coded a non-portable](7bfd7bc) form of including the full path in the call, branch `gz_log_filter_output_jrivero_gzpath`
content.html:
If you have gazebo installed in the system, this gz command probably will use it instead of the compiled one.

I've coded a non-portable form of including the full path in the call, branch gz_log_filter_output_jrivero_gzpath

pull_request.title: Allow `gz log` to output to a file

pullrequest.title: Allow `gz log` to output to a file

content.raw:
Run the `gz log` twice, on the original, and the first output file return different log files. I'm not sure if this is the expected behavior. 

```
jrivero@nium gzserver $ gz log -f state.log -o /tmp/first.log
Warning [parser.cc:536] XML Attribute[version] in element[sdf] not defined in SDF, ignoring.
Error [parser.cc:550] Required attribute[world_name] in element[sdf] is not specified in SDF.
Warning [parser.cc:451] Unable to parse sdf element[state]
Error [parser.cc:362] parse as sdf version 1.6 failed, should try to parse as old deprecated format
jrivero@nium gzserver $ gz log -f /tmp/first.log -o /tmp/second.log
jrivero@nium gzserver $ diff -u /tmp/first.log /tmp/second.log
--- /tmp/first.log	2016-02-24 21:25:09.321992089 +0100
+++ /tmp/second.log	2016-02-24 21:25:22.898244021 +0100
@@ -8,9 +8,6 @@
 <log_end>19 53000000</log_end>
 </header>
 <chunk encoding='zlib'>
-<![CDATA[]]>
-</chunk>
-<chunk encoding='zlib'>
 <![CDATA[]]>
 </chunk>
 <chunk encoding='zlib'>
```
content.html:
Run the gz log twice, on the original, and the first output file return different log files. I'm not sure if this is the expected behavior. 

jrivero@nium gzserver $ gz log -f state.log -o /tmp/first.log
Warning [parser.cc:536] XML Attribute[version] in element[sdf] not defined in SDF, ignoring.
Error [parser.cc:550] Required attribute[world_name] in element[sdf] is not specified in SDF.
Warning [parser.cc:451] Unable to parse sdf element[state]
Error [parser.cc:362] parse as sdf version 1.6 failed, should try to parse as old deprecated format
jrivero@nium gzserver $ gz log -f /tmp/first.log -o /tmp/second.log
jrivero@nium gzserver $ diff -u /tmp/first.log /tmp/second.log
--- /tmp/first.log  2016-02-24 21:25:09.321992089 +0100
+++ /tmp/second.log 2016-02-24 21:25:22.898244021 +0100
@@ -8,9 +8,6 @@
 <log_end>19 53000000</log_end>
 </header>
 <chunk encoding='zlib'>
-<![CDATA[]]>
-</chunk>
-<chunk encoding='zlib'>
 <![CDATA[]]>
 </chunk>
 <chunk encoding='zlib'>

content.raw:
I just notice that if I run `make UNIT_gz_log_TEST` it does not compile the `gz` utility and we are using it in the test. What about declaring the dependency?

```
#!patch
diff -r 0d1b68956eca tools/CMakeLists.txt
--- a/tools/CMakeLists.txt	Tue Feb 23 21:12:14 2016 +0100
+++ b/tools/CMakeLists.txt	Wed Feb 24 20:30:42 2016 +0100
@@ -37,7 +37,9 @@
 
 gz_build_tests(${test_sources})
 
-add_dependencies(${TEST_TYPE}_gz_log_TEST gz)
+if (ENABLE_TESTS_COMPILATION)
+  add_dependencies(${TEST_TYPE}_gz_log_TEST gz)
+endif()
 
 add_executable(gz gz.cc gz_topic.cc gz_log.cc)
 target_link_libraries(gz
```
content.html:
I just notice that if I run make UNIT_gz_log_TEST it does not compile the gz utility and we are using it in the test. What about declaring the dependency?

diff -r 0d1b68956eca tools/CMakeLists.txt
--- a/tools/CMakeLists.txt  Tue Feb 23 21:12:14 2016 +0100
+++ b/tools/CMakeLists.txt  Wed Feb 24 20:30:42 2016 +0100
@@ -37,7 +37,9 @@

 gz_build_tests(${test_sources})

-add_dependencies(${TEST_TYPE}_gz_log_TEST gz)
+if (ENABLE_TESTS_COMPILATION)
+  add_dependencies(${TEST_TYPE}_gz_log_TEST gz)
+endif()

 add_executable(gz gz.cc gz_topic.cc gz_log.cc)
 target_link_libraries(gz

pullrequest.title: Allow `gz log` to output to a file

content.html:
could we get rid of the i extra variable by doing something like:

diff -r 0d1b68956eca tools/gz_log.cc
--- a/tools/gz_log.cc   Tue Feb 23 07:13:40 2016 -0800
+++ b/tools/gz_log.cc   Tue Feb 23 20:19:44 2016 +0100
@@ -837,17 +837,18 @@
     outFile.write(header.c_str(), header.size());
   }

-
   StateFilter filter(!_raw, _stamp, _hz);
   filter.Init(_filter);

-  unsigned int i = 0;
+  if (_raw)
+  {
+    play->Step(stateString)
+    stateString.clear();
+  }
+
   while (play->Step(stateString))
   {
-    if (i > 0)
-      stateString = filter.Filter(stateString);
-    else if (i == 0 && _raw)
-      stateString.clear();
+    stateString = filter.Filter(stateString);

     if (!stateString.empty())
     {
@@ -898,8 +899,6 @@
         outFile.write(stateString.c_str(), stateString.size());
       }
     }
-
-    ++i;
   }

   if (!_raw)

pull_request.title: Allow `gz log` to output to a file

update.description:
Another swarm pull request. We need to filter log files, and produce a new *compressed* log file. 

This pull request adds an output option to `gz log` that allows the tool to filter a log file and write to a new log file.

[Jenkins, the failing test has been fixed](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-none/141/)
update.title: Allow `gz log` to output to a file
